title: Link
summary: A link navigates users to other pages or sections of content.
preamble: The link component is used to navigate users to other pages, sections, or resources. It plays a key role in guiding users through the interface and must be designed for clarity, accessibility, and consistency.

overview.title: Usage
overview.section-content: Use links for navigation — whether it’s within the same page, across pages, or to external sites. A good link is easy to recognize, descriptive, and accessible. It should clearly communicate where it will take the user, even when read out of context (for example, by a screen reader). Avoid using links for actions such as submitting forms or opening modals — use buttons instead.

overview.title: Variants
overview.section-content:
**With leading icon** - Use when an icon helps reinforce the meaning of the link (e.g., a document or download icon before the text).  
**With trailing icon** - Use for links that lead outside the current system, such as external websites. A trailing external link icon helps set expectations.  
**With underline** - Used when a stronger visual indication is needed — for example, in long bodies of text or when links need to stand out clearly from surrounding content.

columns.title: Do
columns.content:
*   Use links only for navigation, not for actions.
    
*   Ensure link text is clear, concise, and descriptive (e.g. “View account details” instead of “Click here”).
    
*   Use icons to clarify the link’s function, especially for external links or downloads.
    
*   Ensure links are accessible: high contrast, visible focus state, and screen-reader friendly.

columns.title: Don´t
columns.content:
*   use vague link texts like “Click here” or “Read more” without context.
    
*   use links to trigger actions like opening modals, submitting forms, or toggling UI—use buttons instead.
    
*   overload an interface with too many link styles—it can confuse users.
    
*   forget to test links in both light and dark modes for contrast and visibility.
